results.title: KKND 2: Krush Kill 'N Destroy Krossfire for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and CD jewel case with insert
results.brief_description: The battle for Earth rages on in the bleak world of KKnD2: Krossfire. The Survivors and Mutes from the previous game are joined by a new enemy: the Series 9. The Series 9 are a robot faction with origins in farm machinery. The radiation from mankind’s wars has warped their programming and they’ve taken up arms against the two original factions, who have destroyed the crops that they were designed to care for. As with the prior games, this game’s focus is resource management, base building, researching upgrades and the creation of units to defeat the other factions.

results.title: KKND: Krush Kill 'N Destroy Xtreme for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and CD jewel case with insert
results.brief_description: A Windows re-release KKND: Krush Kill ‘N Destroy, KKND: Xtreme retains the same gameplay but features more missions, multiplayer maps, a Kaos skirmish mode and updated graphics.

results.title: KKND: Krush Kill 'N Destroy for DOS
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD jewel case with insert and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In the far future of KKND: Krush Kill ‘N Destroy, a nuclear war has destroyed the Earth’s surface. The humans that were left split into two factions: The Survivors are the descendants of humans who managed to burrow under the Earth’s crust before the surface’s annihilation, taking with them what they could salvage. They survived underground for sixty years but dwindling resources has forced them to resurface. They were met by the Mutes, humans who lived through the nuclear destruction, mutated and dominated the Earth. An armed conflict between the two groups is inevitable. The game has you choosing either of these factions. As a classic real-time strategy, the focus on this game is gathering oil, building up and upgrading your base, training units and completing your objectives. Objectives can range from simply destroying an enemy presence to gathering a set amount of materials while fending off enemy attacks.

results.title: International Cricket for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge sleeve and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
International Cricket is one of the only Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) games designed specifically for the Australian market. Melbourne-based Beam Software recreated the cricket pitch in pixels for this iconic game, which simulates a One Day International match and is playable by one to six people, in either single games or round-robin style contests.

Players can bat, bowl and choose to play as big-name cricketers of the day… sort of. Beam Software didn’t get the licenses to use real players, but if you squint hard enough at the character called H. Mervin, you can imagine it’s Merv Hughes.

The game’s AI was notoriously easy to predict but the game’s lack of difficulty didn’t dampen its popularity. Beam Software was also a little difficult to predict – despite working with Nintendo, they cheekily hid images of Sonic the Hedgehog in the game, who was the mascot of rival Sega.

results.title: Halloween Harry for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and CD envelope in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Halloween Harry is set in the 21st century, and features Harry, a ghost hunter, facing off against all sorts of evil across 13 levels. Essentially, it is a platform shooter with some puzzle-solving elements, set on a single screen.

The game instructions, which appear on the start screen, state: ‘It is the 21st century and from this futuristic new world comes an exciting new hero: HALLOWEEN HARRY! As Halloween Harry, a fearless ghost-hunter, you have been assigned to destroy an evil witch who has taken over a 13-room building. You do this by collecting the magic item in each room, then escape through a mystical door. There are 12 items to collect, ranging from a broom in room 1 to a cauldron in room 12. When all the items are collected, you must confront the witch in the 13th room. The witch is protected by a magical barrier, so you must collect a padlock and a key (in any order) so that her defence is broken down… Once exposed, you may zap the witch with your trusty garlic-blaster laser gun, (which has 13 shots). 3 additional shots may be obtained by grabbing the bonus garlic. To make your task difficult, the witch has summoned up various ghosts and ghouls, as well as the dreaded dropjaws and zombie hands to destroy you! Don’t forget there’s a time limit. It can be extended by the magic hourglass that appears when time is low.’

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/halloween-harry/

Last accessed: 11/05/2021

Original game developed by John Passfield. Published in 1985 by HoneySoft.

results.title: Gumboots Australia for DOS
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. One 3 1/2 inch floppy disk and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Explore Australia and help solve a plethora of mysteries in Gumboots Australia. In this this adventure and educational game, the player is tasked with solving cases as an investigator for the Gumboots Enquiry Agency, a job that will take the player all over the country. The player will get to visit locations as varied as Kakadu to Coober Pedy in their hunt for the next clue. Getting there is its own challenge, as different modes of transportation can cost time and money. Random events along the way aid or hinder the player’s quest to solve the case.

results.title: Emulation of Flight of the Amazon Queen for PC
results.material_description:
me01 and ae01
Harvested on 8/05/2020 by Cynde Moya from ARC000090-1﻿ as part of ARC Play It Again II project
results.brief_description:
When Joe King arrives at a Buenos Aires hotel to fly a movie star to a photo shoot, he’s ambushed by rivals who steal his clothes to detain him. To escape, Joe disguises himself as a showgirl and sets off to save the star and stop a mad scientist taking over the world. Featuring a larrikin hero, Amazonian tribes and booby-trapped temples, you can see the influence of Indiana Jones on Flight of the Amazon Queen and likewise it features some outdated references and terminology, but John Passfield and Steven Stamatiadis’ game is emblematic of the popular 1990s point-and-click adventure genre, which often incorporated cinematic storytelling elements.

It’s inspired by games like LucasArts’ Monkey Island (1990), which use on-screen directions like ‘use’, ‘open’, ‘talk to’ and ‘pick up’ to propel the gameplay. In another daring escape – this time down a laundry chute – Joe ‘picks up’ two sheets and ‘uses’ them to create a rope, just one of the many puzzles players solve.
results.title_for_label: Emulation of Flight of the Amazon Queen for PC
results.description:
When Joe King arrives at a Buenos Aires hotel to fly a movie star to a photo shoot, he’s ambushed by rivals who steal his clothes to detain him. To escape, Joe disguises himself as a showgirl and sets off to save the star and stop a mad scientist taking over the world. Featuring a larrikin hero, Amazonian tribes and booby-trapped temples, you can see the influence of Indiana Jones on Flight of the Amazon Queen and likewise it features some outdated references and terminology, but John Passfield and Steven Stamatiadis’ game is emblematic of the popular 1990s point-and-click adventure genre, which often incorporated cinematic storytelling elements.

It’s inspired by games like LucasArts’ Monkey Island (1990), which use on-screen directions like ‘use’, ‘open’, ‘talk to’ and ‘pick up’ to propel the gameplay. In another daring escape – this time down a laundry chute – Joe ‘picks up’ two sheets and ‘uses’ them to create a rope, just one of the many puzzles players solve.
